List
Fiction
THE BEAR AND THE DRAGON, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $28.95.) Aided by the antiterrorism specialist John Clark, President Jack Ryan contends with sinister forces afoot in Russia and China.
THE SWITCH, by Sandra Brown. (Warner, $25.95.) A woman serving as a legendary astronaut's media escort searches for her identical twin sister's killer.
*OPEN HOUSE, by Elizabeth Berg. (Random House, $23.95.) A newly divorced woman attempts to rebuild her life by taking in a series of boarders.
WINTER SOLSTICE, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $27.95.) As Christmas approaches, five lost souls in the north of Scotland discover the healing power of love.
FAITH OF THE FALLEN, by Terry Goodkind. (Tor/ Tom Doherty, $27.95.) In Volume 6 of the ''Sword of Truth'' fantasy series, Richard is captured.

THE BLIND ASSASSIN, by Margaret Atwood. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $26.) The story of two Canadian sisters, one of whom dies in a car crash and leaves behind a science fiction novel that achieves cult status.
THE VOYAGE OF THE JERLE SHANNARA: Ilse Witch, by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $26.95.) The first volume in a fantasy series.
THE INDWELLING, by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins. (Tyndale, $22.99.) Volume 7 in a series about true believers who confront the Antichrist after the rapture of the saved. (+)
FOUR BLONDES, by Candace Bushnell. (Atlantic Monthly, $24.) The love lives of glamorous Manhattan women as seen by the author of ''Sex and the City.''
DUST TO DUST, by Tami Hoag. (Bantam, $25.95.) Two Minneapolis police officers investigate the suspicious death of an Internal Affairs cop.
STALKER, by Faye Kellerman. (Morrow, $25.) While Peter Decker of the L.A.P.D. is distracted by a string of carjackings, someone is terrorizing his daughter.
THE HOUSE ON HOPE STREET, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) A woman with five children must cope with the loss of her husband.
PAGAN BABIES, by Elmore Leonard. (Delacorte, $24.95.) A priest who may not be a priest joins forces with an ex-con looking for her big payday.
PURPLE CANE ROAD, by James Lee Burke. (Doubleday, $24.95.) Dave Robicheaux, a Louisiana sheriff's deputy, searches for his mother's killers.
*NOT A DAY GOES BY, by E. Lynn Harris. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The tumultuous romance between a sports agent and an up-and-coming Broadway star.
*MORGAN'S RUN, by Colleen McCullough. (Simon & Schuster, $28.) A British convict, banished to Australia in 1788, finds a new life and a new love.

Nonfiction
NOTHING LIKE IT IN THE WORLD, by Stephen E. Ambrose. (Simon & Schuster, $28.) The story of the men who built the transcontinental railroad.
LIFE ON THE OTHER SIDE, by Sylvia Browne with Lindsay Harrison. (Dutton, $23.95.) A guided tour of the afterlife, by a ''working psychic.''
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The author tells of his weekly visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
IT'S NOT ABOUT THE BIKE, by Lance Armstrong with Sally Jenkins. (Putnam, $24.95.) A memoir by the Tour de France champion and cancer survivor.
I LOVE YOU, RONNIE, by Nancy Reagan. (Random House, $24.95.) Ronald Reagan's letters to his wife, along with her reflections on them.
SELLOUT, by David P. Schippers with Alan P. Henry. (Regnery, $27.95.) An account of President Clinton's impeachment. (+)
THE ART OF HAPPINESS, by the Dalai Lama and Howard C. Cutler. (Riverhead, $22.95.) What Buddhism tells us about everyday problems.
FLAGS OF OUR FATHERS, by James Bradley with Ron Powers. (Bantam, $24.95.) The story of the six men who raised the flag at Iwo Jima.
ME TALK PRETTY ONE DAY, by David Sedaris. (Little, Brown, $22.95.) A collection of autobiographical comic essays by the author of ''Naked.''
IN THE HEART OF THE SEA, by Nathaniel Philbrick. (Viking, $24.95.) An account of the whaleship Essex, whose disastrous fate inspired Melville.
IN A SUNBURNED COUNTRY, by Bill Bryson. (Broadway, $25.) The author of ''A Walk in the Woods'' reports on his travels through Australia.
THE GREATEST GENERATION, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House, $24.95.) The lives of people who came of age during the Depression and World War II.
DREAM CATCHER, by Margaret A. Salinger. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $27.95.) A memoir of the author's life with her father, J. D. Salinger.
THE FORTUNE TELLERS, by Howard Kurtz. (Free Press, $26.) A journalist describes the Wall Street ''media machine'' and its effect on the stock market.
KITCHEN CONFIDENTIAL, by Anthony Bourdain. (Bloomsbury, $24.95.) A memoir-expose by the executive chef at Brasserie Les Halles in New York.
*HOW TO READ AND WHY, by Harold Bloom. (Scribner, $25.) The Sterling professor of humanities at Yale offers instruction in how to read literary texts.
*EYEWITNESS TO POWER, by David Gergen. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) An adviser to four presidents recalls his years in the White House.

Children's Paperback Books
HARRY POTTER AND THE CHAMBER OF SECRETS, by J. K. Rowling. (Scholastic, $6.99.) A boy returns to a witchcraft school. (Ages 10 and up)
HARRY POTTER AND THE SORCERER'S STONE, by J. K. Rowling. (Scholastic, $6.99.) A British boy attends a school for witchcraft. (Ages 10 and up)
HOLES, by Louis Sachar. (Dell Yearling, $5.99.) A boy is sent to a detention center. (Ages 10 and up)
J. K. Rowling: The Wizard Behind Harry Potter, by Marc Shapiro. (St. Martin's Griffin, $4.99.) An unauthorized biography. (Ages 10 and up)
TEN TIMID GHOSTS, written and illustrated by Jennifer O'Connell. (Cartwheel/Scholastic, $3.25.) A witch tries to rid a house of its ghosts. (Ages 4 to 8)
THE WORLD ALMANAC FOR KIDS 2001. (World Almanac, $10.95.) A reference book. (Ages 9 to 12)
TEENS CAN MAKE IT HAPPEN, by Stedman Graham. (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, $14.) Advice on how to succeed in life. (Ages 13 to 19)
NIGHTMARE HOUR, by R. L. Stine. (Parachute/ Avon, $4.99.) Ten tales of horror by the author of the ''Goosebumps'' series. (Ages 8 to 12)
CHICKA CHICKA BOOM BOOM, by Bill Martin Jr. and John Archambault. Illustrated by Lois Ehlert. (Aladdin, $6.99.) An alphabet chant. (Ages 4 to 8)
TELL ME AGAIN ABOUT THE NIGHT I WAS BORN, by Jamie Lee Curtis. Illustrated by Laura Cornell. (Joanna Cotler/HarperCollins, $5.95.) How one child came into the world. (Ages 4 to 8)
*THE NUMBER DEVIL, by Hans Magnus Enzensberger. Illustrated by Rotraut Susanne Berner. (Metropolitan/Holt, $17.) A boy who hates math is introduced to the wonders of numbers. (Ages 9 to 12)

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending Sept. 9, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+)indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/books. Best-seller lists for children's picture books, children's chapter books and children's paperbacks, respectively, are published in rotation on succeeding weeks; all three lists appear each week on the Book Review's Web site. Publishers have provided the age designations for their best-selling children's titles. Rankings for children's paperbacks do not include serials.
